DOC.brief_summary: Acute renal failure is a common complication in intensive care unit patients. In 10% of cases renal replacement therapy becomes necessary. Current devices have increase filter patency and efficacy. However, magnesium, calcium and phosphate are eliminated as well. However, the extend of this elimination hase not been quantified. Thus, we want to 1. record retrospectively how often abnormal values for phosphate, magnesium and calcium occurred during routine renal replacement therapy in 2011 and 2012. 2. prospectively evaluate the same parameters during routine treatment in 2013 and 2014
DOC.brief_title: Mineral-Homeostasis in Continuous Renal Replacement Therapy
DOC.criteria: intensive care unit patients with acute renal failure undergoing continuous renal replacement therapy older than 18 years of age age less than 18 years pregnancy contraindications against continuous renal replacement therapy
